document: Chapter 4: Access Control - Computer Security: Principles and Practice, 4th Edition

questions.question: Access control is defined by NISTIR 7298 as the process of granting or denying requests to use information or enter facilities.
RFC 4949 defines access control as a process that ignores security policies.
All of computer security is fundamentally concerned with access control.
Role-based access control (RBAC) assigns permissions based on user identity alone.
Discretionary access control (DAC) uses security labels and clearances.
Mandatory access control (MAC) compares security labels with user clearances.
In DAC, an entity cannot grant access rights to another entity.
An access matrix lists subjects on one dimension and objects on the other.
A protection domain is a set of objects with no access rights.
In UNIX, each user has a unique user ID and a group ID.
UNIX file access control uses 10 protection bits.
SetUID allows a program to run with the privileges of the file owner.
The superuser in UNIX is subject to all usual access control restrictions.
Access control lists (ACLs) are not supported in UNIX systems.
Constraints in RBAC help adapt the model to organizational policies.
Attribute-based access control (ABAC) uses only user attributes.
ICAM stands for Identity, Credential, and Access Management.
A credential is an object that binds an identity to a token.
Identity federation allows organizations to trust digital identities from external sources.
The Open Identity Trust Framework is unrelated to identity federation.
DAC is often implemented using an access matrix.
In kernel mode, all memory areas and instructions are accessible.
The sticky bit in UNIX prevents any file in a directory from being deleted.
ABAC policies consider user, resource, and environmental attributes.
RBAC is a type of mandatory access control.
ICAM was developed exclusively by private corporations.
Credential management is not part of ICAM.
Identity management creates trusted digital identities.
MAC is based on the identity of the requestor.
A protection domain row in an access matrix defines user passwords.
UNIX protection bits specify read, write, and execute for owner, group, and others.
SetGID applies the group ID privileges temporarily.
ABAC is also known as policy-based access control.
Federation addresses how to trust identities from external organizations.
In RBAC, roles are static and never change.
A subject in access control can be a user, program, or process.
DAC allows users to pass their access rights to others.
MAC is discretionary because users can change labels.
The owner ID in UNIX is stored in the file's inode.
ICAM's goal is to prevent all access to agency resources.
